Nike (NKE) rival Under Armour (UAA) reported first-quarter results early Thursday that were better than expected, sending shares soaring.Estimates: Swing to a 4-cent per-share loss from prior-year quarter profit of 4 cents a share, as revenue rises 6% to just a little under $1.11 billion.Results: Under Armour lost 1 cent a share as sales climbed to $1.17 billion.Under Armour CEO Kevin Plank said that Steph Curry basketball shoe sales are "sluggish," but said that it is already factored into the company's guidance.Stock: Shares jumped 9.9% to 21.67 on the stock market today, moving above their 50-day moving average for the first time since August 2016.Under Armour is well off its all-time high of 52.95 from September 2015. The stock has come under pressure following investor disappointment from the previous quarter's results, CEO Plank's ill-received comments about President Trump, a lukewarm outing at Kohl's (KSS), and a resurgent Adidas, among other factors.Shares of Nike edged 0.6% higher. U.S. shares of Adidas (ADDYY) fell 0.15%.Leading up to the report, Canaccord Genuity analyst Camilo Lyon expressed last Thursday that he remains cautious on Under Armour."The trifecta of headwinds that plagued (Under Armour) last year (overexposure to sporting goods, overexposure to NA, and overexposure to performance apparel) has not abated, in our opinion," he wrote. "While UA is working to diversify its channel mix as evidenced by its recent entry into KSS (and forthcoming entry into DSW and Famous Footwear later this year), our checks suggest the apparel segmentation efforts have fallen short of expectations."RELATED:Foot Locker Sees Weak Earnings: Here's Why The Stock Is RisingGoogle Backs Up Teens: Nike Rival Under Armour Isn't Hot AnymoreNike Is No Longer The Top New Apparel Brand For Teen Boys: Piper Jaffray SurveyUnder Armour Falls On Tepid Kohl's Debut, 'Intensifying' Price War With Nike

XThe Adidas rocket ship shows no signs of slowing: the latest semiannual teen survey from Piper Jaffray says that the resurgent athletic apparel brand has become the No. 1 new label worn by male teens, knocking out Nike (NKE), the Dow Jones industrial average component that has reigned in that category since fall of 2014.And overall, it the third most preferred fashion footwear brand among upper-income teens, "the highest it has been in 10 years," notes Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy in a separate note, raising her price target to 194 euro from 190. She also notched up full-year estimates on the Three Stripes.That doesn't mean that Nike is anywhere near losing its market share dominance, however. Among all upper-income and average income teens, the Swoosh remains the top athletic clothing brand with 69% of the vote in each segment. Adidas, while still the fastest growing brand in Piper Jaffray's poll, sits in the No. 2 spot with less than 10% of the vote.And in athletic footwear among all teens, Nike holds on tight to its top position with 80% share of the survey."While (Nike) remains the No. 1 footwear brand, we are seeing strong signs that adidas is gaining back share among males & hitting an all-time high with females," said Murphy.Meanwhile, Under Armour (UAA) topped one of the charts in a less stellar way, becoming the No. 1 brand that's no longer being worn by upper-income teenage boys.Under Armour recently was added to midmarket department story Kohl's (KSS), which some analysts wondering if that would undermine the brand. Nike has been at Kohl's and other big-box retailers for years.IBD'S TAKE: Under Armour's first month at Kohl's was considered underwhelming, amid an "intensifying" price war between the Baltimore-based brand and Nike.Dow's Nike fell 0.4% to 54.90 in afternoon trade in the stock market today. Under Armour sank 0.65%, stuck in a long downtrend. Adidas' U.S. shares retreated 0.3%.For all three brands, however, the survey confirms a reassuring trend: activewear is still very in."We have seen the drumbeat for athletic beat louder with every iteration of our Teen Survey," wrote Murphy. "Simply stated, teens — both male & female — are opting for athletic/casual brands as their top apparel & footwear choices."RELATED:Dow Component Nike Earns A Downgrade, Thanks To Under Armour, AdidasWalt Disney Is In Buy Range, And You Can Thank TeensMore Teens Than Ever Expect Next Phone To Be An iPhone: Piper JaffrayLululemon Athletica Plunges Late On Earnings Miss, 'Slow Start' In 2017Finish Line's Dismal Earnings, Guidance Follow Nike's Retail Warning

XAmid a retail landscape that "is not in a steady state," Nike (NKE) CEO Mark Parker said late Tuesday that the company is looking to cut its average product cycle in half and get merchandise to market "in weeks, not months.""I'm convinced now is the time to rewrite the playbook on retail," he said on Nike's third-quarter earnings call.The move is part of what Parker calls a "triple-double" game plan that focuses on innovation, supply chain and marketplace strategy. The initiative involves doubling the "cadence and scale" of innovation, doubling the speed from product insights to delivery to consumer, and doubling the direct connection to customers through digital and personalization efforts, he said on the call.The dominant activewear brand, a Dow component, fell short of Q3 revenue forecasts but delivered a big earnings beat late Tuesday.Management projects mid-single-digit reported revenue growth for the current quarter.In Q3, diluted per-share earnings rose 24% to 68 cents, topping estimates for a year-over-year decline, but 5% revenue growth to $8.43 billion missed the mark. Consensus was for a 4% EPS decline to 53 cents on 5.5% revenue growth to $8.47 billion.Gross margin shrank 140 basis points to 44.5%, said the company, which said higher average selling prices were nevertheless weighed on by "higher product costs, unfavorable changes in foreign exchange rates and the impact of higher off-price sales." Inventories rose 7% from the prior year.North America sales, including footwear, apparel and equipment, rose 3% to $3.78 billion in Q3, excluding currency changes. Western Europe revenue grew 10%. In the greater China region, Nike revenue rose 15%.Shares fell 4% in late trading. The stock cleared a 58.52 buy point on Monday but fell 1.1% to 58.01 by the stock market close Tuesday.Nike was the Dow Jones industrial average's worst performer for the calendar year, sliding 19%, but is up around 14.5% so far this year.Some segments of retail are sadder than others. Department stores and teen retailers are flailing, but there are individual brands that are strong enough to withstand the current choppy waters.Last year was rough on brick-and-mortar stores, and the closures of several sporting-goods chains weighed on athletic brands. But the Swoosh remains the No. 1 sports apparel brand in the world, and "athleisure" looks still fill the sidewalks.Under Armour's (UAA) star has diminished somewhat, in light of a Q4 miss in January and seemingly pro-Trump comments from its chief executive that were ill-received.Meanwhile, Adidas (ADDYY) has emerged as a beast of a contender, upping its outlook four times last year and setting out to reclaim some turf in the key U.S. market.RELATED:Nike Expected To Log First Earnings Decline In Over 4 YearsNike Rival Adidas On U.S. Turf War: Paying The Price For The PastUnder Armour Picks General Motors Vet To Be Chief Innovation OfficerFoot Locker Sprints As Earnings Growth Continues To AccelerateUnder Armour CEO Knocks Trump Policy, But Damage To Cool Factor SeenThat Nike Metric That Sank Shares? Stop Looking At It, Says Nike

X Under Armour (UAA) has a stronger brand than three years ago and people still love wearing activewear — those are the main take-aways from Jefferies' upgrade of the Nike (NKE) rival that are sending shares up early Friday."The bottom has formed," declared the report's headline, as Jefferies analyst Randal Konik upgraded the stock to buy from hold and upped his price target to 27 from 19. He also added Under Armour to the firm's franchise picks list.Why? For one thing, athleisure is a trend that's got stamina: The research firm's survey of 2,000 consumers found that about 25% more of those polled are wearing activewear four to five times a week, almost a third are buying more athletic apparel for themselves, and a quarter more are purchasing more such apparel for their kids.Nike's mixed results Tuesday had some on the Street pointing to competition from Under Armour and, in particular, a resurgent Adidas (ADDYY). Jefferies' poll agrees that Adidas ate into Under Armour's market share, "but gains are moderating" as the Kevin Plank-helmed company makes inroads with children and finds more popularity.IBD'S TAKE: Under Armour got a buy rating from Jefferies, but the stock is in a long downtrend, hitting a 3 1/2-year low as recently as Wednesday. Sales growth has slowed and Wall Street expects the company to post outright losses in the first half of this year. Focus your attention on top-rated companies with strong, even accelerating growth whose stocks are setting up in bullish bases."We were guarded on UA during '16 given Adidas, and UA EPS and stock are down 75% and 50%+, respectively, in 6 mo. predominantly due to share transfer," wrote Konik.But Street estimates aren't taking into account stabilization in the North America market, flattening gross margins, expansion into international markets and category extensions, he said.Konik said his research indicates that "an inflection has formed and the buying (opportunity) is now."Under Armour shares rose 3.6% to 19.66 on the stock market today. On Wednesday, Under Amour fell to 18.40 intraday, its lowest level since September 2013.Nike shares rose 1.8%, regaining their 50-day line after tumbling 7% Wednesday following its weak Q3 sales and margins. Adidas edged lower.Skechers (SKX), which was upgraded to outperform by Cowen & Co., climbed 5.2%. X Athleisure is still a hot fashion trend and strong, loyalty-inducing brands have more buffer room from the brick-and-mortar collapse, meaning Nike (NKE) can't possibly be in a bad spot in retail ... right?Nike has rarely acknowledged the retail climate as weighing on sales. Just three months ago, the No. 1 global athletic brand touted its relative immunity to the choppy waters."Each and every quarter over the past seven years, Nike has grown despite healthy competition within our industry, extreme macroeconomic volatility, discontinuities in the retail landscape and rapidly evolving trends in consumer preferences," said CFO Andy Campion on the Q2 call in December, brushing off any correlation between macroeconomic trends and Nike's growth trajectory.But the tone was noticeably different on Tuesday's call as Campion and CEO Mark Parker both commented during the Q3 call that the North American retail landscape "is not in a steady state."And discounting at the brick-and-mortar level appears to have caught them a bit off guard."Digital disruption and other dynamics are resulting in more aggressive promotional activity than we expected 90-days ago," said Campion late Tuesday. "So we are going to remain tight, with respect to the supply that we are putting into the North America market in the short-term, while aggressively driving the initiatives that will reshape and grow the market, and extend Nike's leadership long-term."Nike's more ominous tone came just as Sears (SHLD) warned "substantial doubt" exists over the iconic department store chain's ability to survive. Meanwhile, other retailers and brands have long brought up the "challenging retail environment" in earnings releases as a way to explain or mitigate lackluster results. Michael Kors (KORS), Signet Jewelers (SIG), Express (EXPR) and others all mentioned some variation of the phrase this past quarter.Shares of Nike, a component on the Dow Jones industrial average, tumbled 7% to 53.92 on the stock market today, diving below their 50-day average and 200-day lines. Rival Under Armour (UAA) rebounded to close up 0.5% after falling intraday to its lowest level since September 2013. U.S.-listed shares of Adidas (ADDYY) dipped 0.5%. Sears sank 12.3%.IBD'S TAKE: Mayhem is the antithesis of convenience, when it comes to shopping. But that is the point. No one wants to stand in line outside for hours waiting for laundry detergent. A Kylie Lip Kit, however, is not long for this world. Is this what will stave off the death of the American mall?"Futures orders," or products scheduled for delivery to retailers, disappointed with a 1% constant-currency decline that included a 9% tumble in North America futures.While Nike has been making attempts to play down the relevancy of this metric, given its aggressive push into direct-to-consumer sales at Nike stores and at Nike.com, the number still has the power to cause consternation.Morgan Stanley analyst Jay Sole, in a Wednesday research note, weighed the possibilities."(U)nprecedentedly weak (North America) futures signal share loss and either a poor retail climate or a radically changing Nike business model," he wrote.But for those worried about Nike's retail performance, "the answer may be the latter," wrote Sole. He said that Nike's new supply chain system might mean that retailers don't have to place futures orders "since Nike can deliver them essentially on demand.""If true, the futures decline isn't alarming," he said.But Nike brand direct-to-consumer revenue grew 13% in Q3, a deceleration from last quarter's 25% growth and the first time in years that the company has not logged DTC growth over 20%.The company, as management likes to say, remains on the offensive.CEO Parker on Tuesday unrolled a new three-pronged attack plan, a "triple-double" initiative built to ramp up product innovation, speed to market and consumer engagement.RELATED:Nike Tanks As Q3 Results Fan Flames Of Adidas' Beast-Mode ComebackNike Vows To Halve Product Cycle To 'Weeks, Not Months'; Stock Falls On Sales, MarginsNike Rival Adidas On U.S. Turf War: Paying The Price For The PastFoot Locker Sprints As Earnings Growth Continues To Accelerate

XIt doesn't take a lot of time learning how to buy a stock using fundamental and technical analysis.Identify a firm showing good earnings and sales growth, and then learn how to tell when mutual funds and other institutional investors, the biggest drivers of a stock's price, are acquiring shares. Bullish chart patterns form when the latter is happening that can lead to powerful upside breakouts, especially in the early stages of a new bull market.After big gains for a stock, though, sell signals often arise. But don't count on the analyst community to tell you when it's happening. When it comes time to sell, they're often late. Sometimes, very late.In June, Deutsche Bank, BofA Merrill Lynch and Needham issued well-timed buys for former leader Acacia Communications (ACIA) just after its IPO. But they haven't issued any sell ratings, even as Acacia has plunged off highs due to bursts of institutional selling by fund managers and other large investors.Acacia quadrupled in price after a breakout from an IPO base with a 32.04 buy point, but signs of institutional selling started to crop up in the stock in early September when shares slumped 6% in higher volume during the week ended Sept. 9 (1). More signs of distribution followed after that.An outright sell signal was triggered in the first half of October when Acacia fell below its 10-week moving average in huge volume (2).The 10-week line is a key support level to watch for a market leader.Meanwhile, in late February, Instinet downgraded shares of Under Armour (UAA) to reduce from neutral after the stock had already fallen more than 50% off its high.But in early May 2016, an IBD story noted a sell signal in Under Armour when the stock fell 8% below a 45.53 cup-with-handle buy point. Since then, shares have fallen another 50%. Cutting bait with a stock when it's not working prevents small losses from spiraling out of control. Sometimes, a stock will rally back after triggering the 7-8% sell rule, but it's a good rule to follow to preserve capital.In late December, an Inside The IBD 50 story noted the sell signals taking place in Nvidia (NVDA). The stock had risen 100% above its 200-day moving average and it had also moved above an upper channel line (seen on a weekly chart by connecting the stock's recent highs since June 2016). Both were signs of a potential climax top seen in past market leaders. Nvidia hasn't completely broken down, but buying demand has dried up as the stock consolidates gains below the 10-week line, about 18% off its high.Stock newsletter writers are known for shelling out a lot of ideas, but after you buy, you're on your own.In the IBD playbook, following sell rules is just as important as following buy rules.Sell signals are annotated on daily and weekly charts in Leaderboard for features like Sector Leaders and the top-10 names in the IBD 50 every day.A break of support at the 50-day moving average (daily chart) or 10-week moving average (weekly chart) in heavy volume as well as cutting losses at 7-8% are annotated when appropriate.IBD also has rules that showcase the time to sell on the way up. For instance, when a stock breaks out and rallies 20%-25% past a buy point, investors will be reminded of an IBD sell rule that says to generally take at least partial profits when a stock's gain hits 20% to 25%, because that's around the time the stock is ready to consolidate gains and perhaps form a new base. Finisar (FNSR) has fallen on hard times lately, but the stock delivered a powerful breakout last summer that yielded a solid gain. It cleared a 19.30 buy point in late July, and then triggered the 20-25% profit-taking rule when the gain hit 20% during the week ended Sept. 9. But shares soared 17% in big volume, fueled by strong earnings.Because of the sign of strength, those with conviction in the stock might've given it a little more room. Those that did were rewarded. The gain hit around 60 in early October just before Finisar settled into a new base.The take-away here is that while taking profits at 20-25% is generally sound strategy, there are some instances where it makes sense to give a potential market leader more room to run.RELATED:When To Sell A Stock I: When The Stock Lives Under Its 10-Week LineWhen To Sell A Stock II: Cutting Losses Fast Is The Best Portfolio DefenseWhen To Sell A Stock III: Get Out When The Leaders In An Industry Group Crumble

President Trump has visions of a massive Apple (AAPL) factory opening in the U.S. to churn out the latest iPhone. The idea is not completely far-fetched, but one thing seems clear: If it happens, most of the new jobs will go to robots.Even in lower-cost China, Foxconn, which assembles the iPhone there, reportedly replaced 60,000 workers with robots at one facility. That's more than half the facility's workforce. Foxconn says it is adding 10,000 "Foxbots" per year.China has seen its cost advantage wither away due to wage gains. It's investing more than $3 billion a year in robots — up from next to nothing before 2009 — to keep from losing its manufacturing base to lower-cost developing nations, Bernstein analysts Michael Parker and Alberto Moel wrote in a December report.Trump has vowed to rewrite or walk away from trade deals and cut corporate tax rates to level the playing field for U.S. companies. He told Congress on Feb. 28 that he'll "bring back millions of jobs."Although economists concur that North American Free Trade Agreement and China's admission to the World Trade Organization have taken a toll on U.S. manufacturing jobs, Trump's battle plan seems geared to fight the last war.If China must shrink its costs with a massive deployment of robots, U.S.-based manufacturers that pay much higher wages and benefits will face the same pressures.A 2015 study by Boston Consulting Group found that an automotive industry welder earned about $25 an hour, including benefits, while a robot could do the job for $8 an hour, including installation, maintenance and operating costs. The gap is expected to widen sharply as technology improves."It is still possible to force the relocation of production" by restricting trade via tariffs or applying political pressure, wrote Bernstein's Parker and Moel. "However, if the point of the exercise is to restore well-paying, middle-class jobs in manufacturing in the process, the result is going to disappoint. Mandating a physical task be carried out in a high-cost labor market in 2017 is simply going to increase the chances the task is automated."Trump relentlessly bashed air conditioning company Carrier during the campaign for its plan to close an Indiana factory and move the work to Mexico. He intervened in December, saving about 800 jobs — for now. But Carrier's parent, United Technologies (UTX), which is getting $7 million in tax incentives from Indiana to stay, said it would invest $16 million to automate the factory "to drive the cost down."Like Apple, United Technologies is a member of Dow Jones industrial average.United Technologies CEO Greg Hayes told CNBC that while moving to Mexico would have been cheaper, the company will "make that plant competitive just because we'll make the capital investments there, but what that ultimately means is there will be fewer jobs."Mondelez (MDLZ), the maker of Oreos, was another regular Trump campaign target for its decision to cut 600 jobs from a Chicago factory and move the work to Mexico. The company said it considered installing new production lines at its Chicago Nabisco plant but chose to do the work in Salinas, Mexico, because of a $46 million cost differential. Mondelez noted that even if the project had gone forward in Chicago, half the jobs would have been eliminated because of new labor-saving technology.IBD'S TAKE: Since taking office, President Trump has talked less about the sticks he'll use against U.S. trading partners and more about the carrots he'll offer to manufacture in the U.S. via tax reform. But, for now, Trump's economic agenda and his tax cuts for business are stuck in line behind the ObamaCare repeal effort.The food and beverage industry is expected to be among the bigger adopters of industrial robots in coming years, says Boston Consulting Group, with automakers and electronics firms continuing to lead the way. Metals and machinery, rubber and plastics, and pharmaceuticals and cosmetics are also seen ramping up robot use. A 2016 McKinsey & Co. study concluded that 59% of manufacturing activities could be automated.Foxconn said in January that it's mulling a $7 billion highly automated factory for making displays, including flat-panel TVs and monitors, in the U.S. in partnership with Apple. Transportation costs for ever-larger displays, which aren't shipped by plane like the iPhone, are a driving force behind the plan. Foxconn Chairman Terry Gou said March 1 that such plans are on hold as the company waits to see what bills are passed and what incentives are offered.Pegatron, another Apple contract manufacturer that does assembly for Dell and HP Inc. (HPQ) out of plants in California and Indiana, reportedly said after Trump's election that it could expand its U.S. capacity fourfold, relying on automation and with a minimal increase in labor. The tech industry began formulating its response last year in the event that Trump was elected and turned out to be serious about imposing 35% tariffs on imports from China.Trump hasn't threatened such hefty tariffs in recent weeks. The focus has shifted to House Republicans' plan to slash the corporate tax rate to 20% and make export revenues tax-free. The 20% rate would apply to the full value of imports, raising $1 trillion over a decade that would effectively pay for the corporate tax cut. Still, economists who back the idea say that the dollar would rise 25%, offsetting any trade advantage. Major importers like Wal-Mart (WMT) hate the idea and trade experts warn that the WTO would likely find the import tax to be illegal.Some companies haven't needed new tax deals or threats to open factories in the U.S., but automation is key to their strategies.Adidas is a prime example. The maker of athletic shoes, which has long done its labor-intensive manufacturing out of China, Indonesia and Vietnam, last year piloted what it's calling a Speedfactory in Germany, making shoes almost entirely by robots. This year, the second Adidas Speedfactory is slated to open in Atlanta, where it's expected to employ 160 people facilitating the production of a half-million shoes.The high-tech operation, Adidas says, won't just eliminate the drudgery in manufacturing (along with a lot of the workers). It also will enable the company "to make product for the consumer, with the consumer, where the consumer lives in real time, unleashing unparalleled creativity and endless opportunities for customization."Meanwhile, Nike (NKE), another Dow industrials component, and Under Armour (UAA) are both developing strategies for manufacturing in the U.S., close to their customers. It's a safe bet that robots will be doing most of the work.The implications for workers are clear, says Boston Consulting Group. "As U.S. factories adopt advanced manufacturing technologies, demand will surge for higher-skilled, white-collar workers who can quickly adapt to new technologies and processes, and demand will lessen for blue-collar workers who are trained in specific skills."Despite his vow to bring back millions of jobs, Trump isn't oblivious to the job threat posed by robots. In a postelection interview, the New York Times asked Trump whether he was worried that companies will keep their factories in the U.S. but automate their workers out of jobs."They will, and we'll make the robots too," Trump said. He added: "Right now we don't make the robots. We don't make anything. But we're going to. I mean, look, robotics is becoming very big and we're going to do that."Trump is more right than wrong about the U.S. ceding an opportunity, writes Frank Tobe, publisher of the Robot Report. "Two-thirds of the robotics industry and 100% of industrial robots are manufactured outside of the U.S. by non-U.S. companies."China's leadership has fully embraced the adoption of robots as part of its "Made in China 2025" strategy. The plan reflects not only wage pressures but demographics, as its working-age population shrinks. Whether the U.S. will avoid committing to robots for fear of displacing workers is a real question with serious competitive implications.Academics and industry leaders made the case in "A Roadmap for U.S. Robotics" last fall that robots have been a plus for manufacturing jobs. "Over the last 5-6 years we have seen introduction of 600,000 new jobs in manufacturing. During the same period, we have seen significant growth in adoption of robot systems in industry," they wrote.Yet their upbeat predictions come with some uncertainty. The auto industry has been the biggest adopter of robotics, but that's happened as sales rebounded from just 10.4 million in 2009 to a record high 17.5 million in 2016. But if demand has peaked, as industry players suspect, then increasing automation may not be quite so positive for employment in auto manufacturing in the future.RELATED:U.S. Manufacturing Gears Up As 'America First' Trump Takes OfficeThe Top 10 Jobs Robots Could Steal From Humans By 2025Forget The Doomsday Clock, There's Now A Robot Fear IndexThe Trump Economy: Jobs, Regulations, Taxes And Trade

Under Armour (UAA) on Monday named General Motors (GM) veteran Clay Dean its chief innovation officer.He will be responsible for "global vision and strategy for Innovation, and cross-functional collaboration with its internal Design, Marketing, Product, and Category Management team," according to the release, and will report to Kevin Haley, Under Armour's head of category management and innovation.Dean was most recently the design director for General Motors' Global Advanced Design unit.Under Armour shares fell 1.1% to 17.56 on the stock market today. Rival Nike (NKE), a Dow Jones industrial average component, rose 0.4% at 56.67.Under Armour's brand image has taken a hit in 2017, after CEO Kevin Plank made seemingly pro-Trump remarks on CNBC, then took out a full-page ad in the Baltimore Sun to oppose the travel ban and clarify his stances.Meanwhile, Adidas continues to power higher, retaking the No. 2 spot from Under Armour in the U.S. in recent months and delivering strong fourth-quarter results last week."While we're happy with the No. 2 spot, we're happy with the progress — we're actually not happy where we are overall as a company," Adidas CEO Kasper Rorsted told Investor's Business Daily last week.RELATED:Nike Rival Adidas On U.S. Turf War: Paying The Price For The Past  Under Armour CEO Knocks Trump Policy, But Damage To Cool Factor Seen

XBy all accounts, Adidas (ADDYY) had a whopper of a year. The athletic powerhouse ramped up its outlook no less than four times and grew currency-neutral revenue by 18% in 2016.The years ahead are also looking good, and on Wednesday the Nike (NKE) rival raised its long-term sales and earnings guidance.Shares, which trade in the U.S. on the OTC market, leapt as high as 92.31 in afternoon trading on the stock market today, a new all-time high. Adidas' stock gained 62% in 2016.Nike shares, by contrast, tumbled 19% last year, making it the worst performer on the Dow Jones industrial average. Shares edged down 0.1% to 56.51 Wednesday.Despite Adidas' momentum,  Kasper Rorsted — who took over as CEO from Herbert Hainer last fall — nevertheless has his sights set on driving growth even higher, particularly in the key North American market where the brand has until recently dragged."It's important to understand we've been in the U.S. for many years, but we've not executed appropriately in the U.S.," he told Investor's Business Daily via phone from the company's German headquarters. "And that has given room for a Nike to grow, and also an Under Armour."Adidas has in recent months recaptured the No. 2 spot by sales in the U.S. from smaller rival Under Armour (UAA), according to NPD Group data, and in January doubled its U.S. athletic footwear market share to 10% from the prior year.Nike held the lead with 45%, while Under Armour had 2% market share in January, said NPD."While we're happy with the No. 2 spot, we're happy with the progress — we're actually not happy where we are overall as a company," said Rorsted. He added that the company is in "catch-up mode" despite being the second biggest athletic brand, and "we should have substantially higher market share and position in the U.S. than we have today.""But right now, that is the only market where we're paying the price for the past," he said.The company, which plans to "continue to invest over-proportionately into its U.S. business," is in the midst of implementing a new long-term "Creating the New" strategic initiative. Rolled out two years ago, it includes a focus on speed to market, presence in key metropolitan cities and consumer engagement in order to accelerate growth.Adidas is now looking to shed its hockey business, in addition to its golf brands, as the company focuses on its stronger brands and core segments.Fourth-quarter sales and net income beat consensus figures, according to Piper Jaffray, which has an overweight rating on Adidas and raised its price target on Wednesday to 190 euros.Currency-neutral sales in Q4 grew 14%, including 29% year-over-year growth in North America and 25% growth in its greater China segment.Calling the North America segment a "bright spot," Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy also noted that Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS), Foot Locker (FL) and Journeys "are all seeing better Adidas shelf space in 2017."For 2017, Adidas expects 11%-13% in currency-neutral revenue growth, better than current estimates. Management intends to shed more light on the details at Adidas' analyst day next week.The company said it now expects 10%-12% in average annual sales growth between 2015-2020, up from prior guidance for a high-single-digit rate. It also sees 20%-22% in average annual growth in net income from continuing operations for that period, up from previous outlook for about 15% a year on average.In addition to retro trends riding high in the U.S. — iconic Adidas shoes such as the Stan Smith and Superstar are major fashion favorites right now — Adidas' Boost, NMD and Kanye West-designed Yeezy designs are all enjoying popularity."Creating the kinds of sneakers American kids want has had a major impact on their business," said NPD sports industry analyst Matt Powell. "I called them brand of the (year) in 2016 and am about ready to do the same in 2017."

Storefront retail has become a dreary landscape, and even more littered with dismal news after a trying holiday season. Holiday-quarter reports showed weak foot traffic and soft, if not declining, same-store sales. Consumers aren't buying less, but it has become the conventional wisdom that Amazon.com (AMZN) is murdering all but the best malls, and that young people prefer experiences to tangible products…

The top executive at Under Armour (UAA) is a fan of President Trump. His top athletes aren't. Let the fireworks begin.Three of the clothing company's biggest names spoke out against Chief Executive Kevin Plank after he publicly praised the Republican president, declaring on CNBC that Trump is a "real asset for the country." Plank is a member of the administration's American Manufacturing Council."I agree with that description — if you remove the 'et' (from asset)," NBA superstar Stephen Curry reportedly said recently. Curry is Under Armour's most prized sneaker pitchman.On Thursday, Misty Copeland, a star ballet dancer prominently featured in Under Armour advertising, came out against Plank's statements in a post on Instagram. Copeland said she spoke at length with the CEO and hoped the company would take public action to promote inclusivity."I strongly disagree with Kevin Plank's recent comments in support of Trump," said Copeland. "Those of you who have supported and followed my career know that the one topic I've never backed away from speaking openly about is the importance of diversity and inclusion."Dwayne Johnson, known as "The Rock" to wrestling fans, had some strong words to share as well. The actor, who has an apparel line with Under Armour, said yesterday that the CEO's comments trampled the beliefs of many of the company's employees.Leaders are supposed to inspire people, not "divide and disband," he said."These are neither my words, nor my beliefs," Johnson said of Plank's statement. "His words were divisive and lacking in perspective."The White House declined to comment on the statements, and Under Armour didn't respond to requests for comment. On Wednesday, a spokesperson for the company did say the clothier engages "in policy, not politics," and that it advocates for fair trade, inclusive immigration, and tax reform.Competition for top athletes is cutthroat among the world's biggest performance wear companies, and star power is a valuable resource in the battle to be cool among teens and other sneakerheads. LeBron James signed a shoe deal with Nike last year reportedly worth more than $1 billion. Curry alone has spearheaded Under Armour's basketball business, with annual footwear sales hitting $1 billion for the first time in 2016.By taking a political stance, Under Armour risks alienating those athletes who view Trump negatively, and at a time when the brand's cool factor is already lackluster. After reporting disappointing earnings in January, Plank said the brand needed to "become more fashion" and get off the court and onto the streets. Plank said the brand needs to become a casual lifestyle staple, a segment currently ruled by Nike (NKE).Meanwhile, several members of the New England Patriots have so far vowed to skip the traditional White House visit after having won the Super Bowl on Sunday. Tampa Bay Buccaneers star wide receiver Mike Evans protested Trump's election at a game.High-profile basketball coaches Steve Kerr, Stan Van Gundy, and Gregg Popovich have criticized him, too. So did James and other NBA players, including Luol Deng and Jeremy Lin. One notable exception is Tom Brady, the Patriots quarterback and Under Armour athlete who counts Trump as a friend.Meanwhile, Under Armour's closest rivals, Nike and Adidas, each condemned Trump's executive order banning refugees from seven Muslim-majority countries, an order which was temporarily blocked by a federal appeals court last night. Nike CEO Mark Parker wrote in a memo to employees in January that his company's values were being "threatened" by the order."This is a policy we don't support," Parker wrote in the letter. "We are at our best when we recognize the value of our diverse community."

Once the cool new kid, Under Armour (UAA) is now sitting solo at the proverbial high-school cafeteria table after being perceived as getting chummy with the school bully.Following high-profile backlash to seemingly pro-Trump remarks in a recent CNBC interview, Under Armour CEO Kevin Plank has since clarified his statement, even taking out a full-page ad in the Baltimore Sun on Wednesday to highlight the company's values, which include equal rights, job creation, and a pro-immigration stance."We are publicly opposing the travel ban," detailed the letter. "With an anticipated new executive order on immigration set to come out, we will join a coalition of companies in opposition to any new actions that negatively impact our team, their families or our community."Last week, Plank told CNBC that having a pro-business president was "a real asset to this country," sparking headlines that the Under Armour chief was in favor of Trump, while leaders from Netflix (NFLX), Starbucks (SBUX) and elsewhere have been vocal in criticizing the president's actions, particularly on immigration.Nevertheless, the damage seems to have been done, and according to one analyst, it's going to take a while for the Nike (NKE) rival to shake off its newly acquired bad rap."Commentary by the CEO in a CNBC interview in a polarized political climate, and pointed response by Stephen Curry, The Rock, and Misty Copeland make it nearly impossible to effectively build a cool urban lifestyle brand in the foreseeable future," wrote Susquehanna analyst Sam Poser, referring to the brand's endorsers who have spoken out against Plank's comments.Poser, a longtime bull on Under Armour, has downgraded his rating twice in less than three weeks.Disappointing Q4 results last month spurred Susquehanna's initial cut from positive to neutral, but the latest slash to negative (read: sell) is mostly driven by the "reputational risk" that the athletic apparel brand now faces in the wake of those comments.In a report that was written and published prior to seeing Plank's Baltimore Sun letter, Poser also highlighted the high anti-Trump political sentiment at the Grammy Awards on Sunday, noting that Nike and Adidas both ran commercials "celebrating each brand's relationship to the community.""It is clear to us and UAA management that Under Armour needs to build its casual and lifestyle business in order to return to historical growth rates," said Poser. "Unfortunately, the brand's cool factor is generally dictated by the style influencers who were likely insulted by CEO Plank's comments, or at least the media's characterization of his comments."Poser also called for Plank to get "on air, in person, and fully address the issues facing Under Armour," adding that corporate releases lack perceived sincerity.Shares of Under Armour edged up 0.6% to close at 21.89 on the stock market today. Nike shares rose 0.3% to 56.64.IBD's TAKE: Shoppers threatened to boycott Under Armour for Plank's comments. The brand isn't the only retailer finding itself at the center of a Trump-related controversy. Nordstrom and Sears have both made headlines for dropping certain Trump-affiliated items from their product assortments.The Susquehanna analyst also cited challenges in building a lifestyle brand and said Under Armour's $55 hoodies and other items are "too basic." He slashed his price target on the stock to 14 from 24.Conversely, Morgan Stanley analyst Jay Sole — a longtime Under Armour bear — on Tuesday upgraded the stock to equal weight from underweight, in light of the lower valuation. He has a 20 price target on Under Armour."The stock price suggests the market now believes (Under Armour) is a much more mature brand than it previously thought," wrote Sole.RELATED:Sears Dumps Some Trump-Branded Goods But Aims To 'Leave The Politics To Others'President Trump Attacks Nordstrom To Defend Daughter's Business

The office, in lower Manhattan, has all the markings of a tech startup. There are high ceilings and a cool warehouse vibe, craft beer is on tap in the kitchen, and the place is buzzing with twentysomethings.But they aren't trying to make the next hit mobile app. The big idea here is to disrupt another ubiquitous product."There were so many evolutions in technology, but underwear was stuck in, like, the early 1900s,'' said Tom Patterson, founder of Tommy John, which makes premium skivvies for men. "It was a very sleepy category."Tommy John is part of a growing drive by fledgling brands to get men to rethink underwear and pay more for it.It isn't easy. The $8 billion category has long been an afterthought. Many guys restocked only after ridicule from a significant other, or when disintegration could no longer be denied. Thanks to fellow upstarts such as Mack Weldon, guys are giving this everyday item more consideration.Skivvies ranging from $25 to $70 a pair now come with a list of features as long as those that once came with lawnmowers and television sets. They are "game-changing products," with moisture control, cool zones, and stealth waistbands. They can be Swiss-made, breathable, anti-microbial, and anti-odor. Tommy John even reconfigured the front flap and developed a "Quick Draw" fly for easier access.All this has boosted spending. In the past three years, the average price for a pair of underwear in the U.S. has risen by a third, while prices for men's apparel overall have declined by about the same amount, according to research by Fung Global & Retail Technology and First Insight. Global sales are expected to increase from $8.4 billion in 2015 to $11 billion by 2020, according to Persistence Market Research.The disruption is a testament to the power of "premiumization," a strategy that over the past decade has swept through many once-mundane categories.While many take it for granted, there was a time when grocery stores didn't have a dozen kinds of coffee. When the only consideration for buying ground beef was price, not what the cows ate. When a workout shirt was a cheap basic, far from the innovation story shoppers pay more for today. People never used to talk about how much they loved such things as water bottles and blenders.Now men's underwear, of all things, is being transformed.Premiumization is all about resetting expectations with additional choices and benefits. Under Armour (UAA) revolutionized workout gear with polyester shirts that made sweat evaporate better than cotton did. Starbucks (SBUX) became a behemoth by introducing a slew of new tastes and styles to America's coffee drinkers, whose choices had stopped at sugar, milk or cream."Because this happened, it doesn't mean everything will be disrupted," said Adam Burgoon, a partner at investment fund KarpReilly, which owns a stake in Mack Weldon. The size of the market for such refashioned underwear remains to be seen, Burgoon said, because many guys are likely to balk at the price. "But it means probably everything can be disrupted," he said.Men's underwear was especially ready for a change. Not only was it largely devoid of innovation, such industry leaders as Calvin Klein were mostly focused on winning over women, because they bought most of the underwear.It was primarily a fashion business with a buffet of patterns and colors. The marketing featured images like Calvin Klein's buff young Mark Walhberg up on billboards, and packaging showing expressionless youngsters with six-pack abs.Yet men were settling down later in life, and so doing more shopping on their own in the interim. Being single longer made them care more about their appearance, which has disrupted other categories, such as skin care and jeans. The underwear startups' marketing is more approachable. Some of it uses middle-aged models and pushes fun and honesty over sexy slickness."I never really related to traditional underwear advertising,'' said Patterson, the Tommy John founder. "It was too serious. It was weird. We just say it like it is. We're the first brand to have a no-wedgie guarantee. You're not supposed to talk about wedgies with underwear. The fact of the matter is that 100% of men get a wedgie at some point in their lives."Patterson got the idea for Tommy John last decade, from a much different place than sexy. While wearing a suit as a medical-device salesman, he found his underwear was even more uncomfortable than usual. He set about to solve a problem, not to go wild with beefcake and polka dots.The early years were difficult. Direct selling on the web wasn't as viable, so he had to pitch department-store buyers, who were mostly women. Patterson's break came in 2009, when he won over Neiman Marcus by getting the woman who ran the underwear department to let her husband and male colleagues test his product.From there, the idea of selling men's underwear to men gained steam and has exploded in recent years. There's been a rush of startups, helped by lower barriers to entry. Sourcing from Asia has never been easier, and the internet has slashed marketing costs. That has allowed brands like Mack Weldon to sell only directly, through its website.Today, a majority of men's underwear is purchased by men, a reversal from a decade ago. Amid a dizzying number of choices, men are indulging: Tommy John and Mack Weldon each more than doubled sales last year.Young brands are also going beyond products and revamping how items are purchased. New York-based Basic Outfitters offers a ''create-a-drawer'' option that makes things really easy for guys by offering underwear, socks, undershirts, and joggers in one package for $60."Men really are rethinking what they want,'' said Matthew Congdon, Mack Weldon's creative director and former top underwear designer for Calvin Klein. It used to be about "an oversize logo or a slicker pattern or print," he said. "Now it's about innovation, the fit, the fabric, and the waistband. Something that is for him."

Soft traffic and disappointing apparel and equipment sales during the key holiday quarter weighed on Hibbett Sports' (HIBB) fourth-quarter same-store sales, hitting shares of the athletic specialty retailer and at least one of its counterparts Tuesday morning.Ahead of its March 10 earnings release, Hibbett announced preliminary Q4 net sales of $246.9 million, marking growth of half a percent from the prior-year quarter. But comparable store sales fell 2.2% for the all-important shopping period.Hibbett, which has over 1,000 stores in the U.S., carries Nike (NKE), Under Armour (UAA), Adidas and other brands among its product assortment."We continued to experience strength in our footwear business, which was a direct result of our improved assortments and in-stocks by store types," said Hibbett CEO Jeff Rosenthal in a release. "As traffic declined and sales softened, we became more promotional in order to drive sales and manage inventory, which had a negative impact on gross margin."Hibbett expects 53-55 cents in diluted per-share earnings for the period, well below current Street forecasts for 61 cents a share.For fiscal 2018, the company sees flat to low-single-digit range same-store sales and $2.65-$2.85 in EPS, the midpoint of which is shy of current views for $2.77 a share.Shares of Hibbett sank nearly 12% to end the regular trading session at 29.35 on the stock market today, hitting the lowest level in more than a year. Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) slipped 1.3% to 51.75, even as it announced a 12% increase in its quarterly dividend Tuesday morning, while Foot Locker (FL) edged up 0.3% to 70.64. Nike added 0.6% to 56.45 and Under Armour climbed 2.1% to 21.76.

Analyst George Askew says the company appears to have implemented a price hike of about 50% "on leads within its Premier Agent program for new contracts."IBD previously reported that Zillow rolled out a new dynamic approach to pricing of its Premier Agent ads. Shoe and athletic-apparel chain Foot Locker (FL) reported strong fourth-quarter earnings on Friday as same-store sales popped.Earnings per share rose 18% to $1.37, the third straight quarter of accelerating growth. Analysts expected $1.32. Revenue grew 6% to $2.11 billion, in line with views. Same-store sales jumped 5%, better than forecasts for 4.6%.Foot Locker cited strong demand for Nike (NKE) shoes as well as some Adidas footwear. But it didn't mention struggling Under Armour (UAA), which already reported weak holiday results.Foot Locker sees current-year EPS rising by double digits vs. consensus for a 11% gain.Shares surged 9.4% to close at 75.01 on the stock market today, vaultiing over its 50-day moving average. Nike, which depends on Foot Locker for a lot of its sales, gained 0.8%. Under Armour edged 0.7% higher.Finish Line (FINL), another mall-based athletic shoe retailer, advanced 2.9%. Sporting goods chains Hibbett Sports (HIBB)  and Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) climbed 2.6% and 1.9%, respectively.Earlier this month, Hibbett reported weak apparel and equipment sales during Q4 and gave weak guidance, ahead of its full Q4 report next month.Concerns have lingered that consumers were growing weary of the basketball genre as interest in more casual sneakers grows. While Nike management said in December that it is seeing "incredible momentum" in basketball and that "basketball is back," Foot Locker, in November, said it saw lukewarm results in the basketball-shoe category during the third quarter.In addition to struggling under Amazon's (AMZN) retail choke-hold, the sports retail industry last year contended with the bankruptcies of chains like Sports Authority and Sports Chalet.Those chains may have drawn many bargain-seeking shoppers away from companies in better shape. Other analysts say Sports Authority customers have yet to make the leap to other athletic chains in the wake of the bankruptcy, according to Footwear News.In Q3 however, Foot Locker said U.S. store traffic increased. Casual throwback sneakers from Adidas, Puma and others have also helped sales. The company has also benefited from more health-conscious lifestyle and what it has called a "casualization" of the way people around the world wear clothing, although concerns about "peak athleisure" exist elsewhere.RELATED:How Mayhem, Drama Can Help The American Mall Cheat DeathUnder Armour CEO Knocks Trump Policy, But Damage To Cool Factor Seen

The "Amazon (AMZN) effect" is well documented. Foot traffic at brick-and-mortar stores across America are declining as people spend their dollars online.But it's also shaping what is perhaps the new normal among department stores and other retailers as they fight for market share through a beefier online presence.At Kohl's (KSS), sales for the key holiday quarter were "weak," said CEO Kevin Mansell in the company's earnings release Thursday, as brick-and-mortar traffic declined. But that softness was "offset somewhat by strength in online demand."Kohl's shares fell 2.1% to 40.91 in the stock market today. For the key holiday quarter, total sales fell almost 3% to $6.21 billion, missing views for $6.22 billion, as comparable store sales drooped 2.2%. Per-share profit fell 9% to $1.44, besting expectations by 11 cents. Kohl's also raised its dividend by 10% to 55 cents.Fellow department store Macy's (M) logged similar Q4 results on Tuesday, with sales and comps down but "double-digit growth" in its online business.Wal-Mart (WMT) on Tuesday boasted a 29% U.S. e-commerce gain as its overall 1% revenue gain came up short.Soft in store, strong online is a recurring theme. Target's (TGT) November-December comparable store sales fell 3% as digital sales popped 30%. (That discounter reports next week.)But online sales are still a fraction of traditional stores' business, so it's hard for even strong e-commerce gains to move the needle.IBD'S TAKE: In an e-commerce-driven consumer landscape, the raison d'etre of malls is waning. Some shopping arenas are calling on mayhem and drama to boost foot traffic.Reducing store count is one way to combat crummy foot traffic. Kohl's said it closed 19 locations in 2016 and opened nine small-format locations, as well as a number of outlets.Macy's is 66 stores into its 100-store closure plan. The rest will be shuttered over the next few years. That will give the department store operator a "healthy physical portfolio" that will complement its growing online sales, said CEO Terry Lundgren on the Macy's earnings call on Tuesday.But the kicker is: as department stores close more stores, that may only in turn weigh on their e-commerce sales."Our customers buying online love to return in store," said Macy's CFO Karen Hoguet on the same call. "They love to shop in store, buy online. So we are, I think, forever going to lose some of that Macys.com business when we close a single-store market."Macy's shares rose 0.3% on Thursday but are continuing to find resistance at their 50-day line.Wal-Mart has taken a slightly different tack with its acquisition of smaller Amazon rival Jet.com and its push into online groceries. That helped drive its strong online sales gain as the big box retailer also gave bullish overall revenue guidance. Wal-Mart's 29% online sales gain is faster than Amazon's overall revenue growth of 22%, and that's flattered by its Amazon Web Services cloud division."We're the second-largest U.S. online retailer by revenue, one of the top three online retailers by traffic and our Wal-Mart app is among the top three apps in retail," said Wal-Mart CEO Doug McMillon on the call Tuesday.Wal-Mart shares fell 0.6% on Thursday but are still up solidly for the week.Wal-Mart recently dropped its Amazon Prime membership rival and announced that it would offer free two-day shipping for minimum orders of $35. Amazon this week dropped its free shipping minimum order to $35 for non-Prime members, but deliveries will take five to eight business days.Meanwhile, faster fashion and athleisure — two other ongoing trends — appear to be on the minds of Kohl's execs going into the new fiscal year."In 2017, we will accelerate our focus on becoming the destination for active and wellness with the launch of Under Armour (UAA) in early March," said Mansell. "We will also extend our efforts on improving our speed to market across all of our proprietary brands into all apparel areas and home."Kohl's said it expects $3.50 to $3.80 in diluted per-share earnings for fiscal 2017 and a 1.3% decline to 0.7% growth in total sales, vs Wall Street forecasts for $3.73 EPS on flattish sales.Comps are expected to range from a decline of 2% to flat sales for the year.Nordstrom (JWN) reported so-so results and guidance late Thursday. The upscale department store said Nordstrom.com sales topped $2.5 billion in 2016, more than 17% of total revenue. Nordstrom shares closed down 3.1% during the regular session, but recouped those losses late.RELATED:Wal-Mart Gives Strong Revenue Guidance As Q4 Online Sales Soar 29%Macy's Eyes 'Entertainment Options' After Profit, Sales Fall For 8th Quarter

Under Armour (UAA) shares are in a tailspin Tuesday after fourth-quarter earnings disappointed and the athletic apparel brand said CFO Chip Molloy is stepping down "due to personal reasons."During the key holiday shopping season, the Nike (NKE) rival logged a penny's profit decline from the prior-year to 23 cents a share on 12% revenue growth to $1.308 billion, the weakest gain in eight years. North American sales grew just 6% while international revenue (16% of the total) jumped 55%.Analysts had expected a 4% EPS rise to 25 cents with sales up 20% to $1.409 billion."Numerous challenges and disruptions in North American retail tempered our fourth quarter results," said Kevin Plank, Under Armour Chairman and CEO, in a statement.The quarter is prompting something of a reset — at least of Plank's well-known whiteboard. He scrubbed the board clean of his maxims and motivational phrases (most notably "Don't forget to sell shirts and shoes") and replaced it with "Keep Under Armour simple," he said during the earnings call.For 2017, management expects net revenue to rise 11%-12% to reach nearly $5.4 billion, well below analyst views for $6.05 billion. Along with this "tempered" sales growth, "strategic investments" will lead to a drop in operating income.Shares crashed nearly 26% to 21.49 in the stock market today, setting a three-year low. Under Armour is on track for its worst one-day stock loss since it came public in 2005.The guidance left one analyst wondering if the brand might be struggling more than it is letting on."The revenue guidance is peculiar given the rollout into Kohl's (KSS)," wrote Susquehanna's Sam Poser, who downgraded the stock to neutral from positive. "However, the decision to go to the moderate channel may have been more reactive than we had previously thought."Athletic footwear stocks have largely been having a tough go of it for the last year. Under Armour, Nike and Skechers (SKX) all posted double-digit share-price declines in 2016 amid a tough consumer environment. NPD Group said Monday that the athletic footwear industry grew a below-average 3% in 2016, with slight declines during the holiday quarter as the bankruptcies of Sports Authority and Sport Chalet.Nike stock fell 0.3% intraday, but rebounded from morning lows to close back above its 50-day line. Skechers rose 0.8% after undercutting its 50-day intraday.And as retro and classic trends rule the sneaker set, Under Armour is acknowledging that the brand does not have as much fashion cred as it could."We need to become more fashionable with the products that are out there," said Plank during the call. He said the company had been counting on core basics, but today's consumer "frankly has more options" from good brands that are discounting their prices, he said."The consumer expects more today, he later added.Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy, who downgraded the stock from overweight to neutral, noted the slowdown."By segment, apparel grew only 7% — well below the 17% growth rate we anticipated and while footwear was still a healthy 36%, we see the slowing apparel as a significant concern to the brand given the importance of this category," she wrote.But Plank, predictably, still sounded bullish on the future, particularly the China and womenswear markets."Our eyes are wide open and we're ready to run in 2017 and beyond," he said.When Molloy steps down, senior VP David Bergman will take over as acting CFO on Feb. 3, said Under Armour.RELATED:Spring Retail Playoffs: J.C. Penney-Nike Vs. Kohl's-Under ArmourDow Dog Nike Comes Out Swinging; Bullish On North America, BasketballUnder Armour Dives On Growth Targets; Execs Vow To Invest 'Aggressively'

Is Under Armour (UAA) running out of steam? Will it report decent holiday-quarter sales? Have we reached peak "athleisure"?Depends on who you ask. But first, a quick recap.When the Nike (NKE) rival reports fourth-quarter results Tuesday morning, earnings are expected to rise a penny, or 4%, from last year's Q4 to 25 cents a share, while revenue is seen growing 20% to $1.41 billion, which would mark a sequential slowdown on both fronts.Last quarter's solid beat was overshadowed by lowered growth projections, sending Under Armour shares down over 13% and into a slump from which they have not recovered.Management emphasized that the trimmed forecast came in exchange for growth-focused investments, but the revised target for midteens annual operating income growth (vs. prior outlook for 23% growth) has apparently been sitting well with investors.Athletic brands have been on the defensive lately, with Nike management coming out swinging on its earnings call last month as it insisted that "basketball is back" and that Nike is "well-positioned" for the latter half of its fiscal year.IBD'S TAKE: Under Armour is just one of many notable earnings reports. Be prepared for the coming market day with IBD's Investing Action Plan. Today's action plan highlights Tuesday earnings from Apple, Exxon, MasterCard, AMD and more.More broadly, Under Armour shares have slid over 30% in the last year. Its peers haven't fared much better. Nike — the biggest underperformer on the Dow in 2016 — is down 15% over the trailing 12 months, while Skechers (SKX) has fallen 13%.Under Armour shares fell 0.65% to 28.94 on the stock market today, close to a two-and-a-half-year low set on Jan. 23. Nike and Skechers shares dipped 0.2%.So what to expect on Tuesday?Retailers generally didn't have a great Christmas shopping season, and NPD Group data hint at a potentially troubled holiday picture for gym-shoe makers as well.Research firm NPD said Monday that the overall U.S. athletic footwear industry grew a below-average 3% in 2016, logging gains through the first three quarters of the year but declining "slightly" in the all-important holiday quarter.The bankruptcies of Sports Authority and Sport Chalet weighed on Q4, said NPD sports industry analyst Matt Powell in a release. He sees the impact of the retail closures ending after Q1.Cowen found Under Armour's promotional activity over the holidays "concerning," but analyst John Kernan said shares are "already discounting bad news" and highlighted that the brand continues to gain market share from Nike in apparel.Kernan has a market perform rating on Under Armour.Morgan Stanley analyst Jay Sole, a noted Under Armour bear, said that the company's Q4 results will "indicate its sales growth rate is slowing more than the market expects," with the "most acute" issues being in Under Armour's women's and basketball shoe segments.Calling Under Armour "a much more mature brand than the market realizes," Sole has an underweight rating on the stock.Under Armour bulls believe otherwise. Susquehanna's Sam Poser, who has a positive rating on the name, says Under Armour is "playing the long-game," and says " the decision to slow profit flow-through is, in a telling way, indicative of all that is right about the way Under Armour is approaching its business."And Piper Jaffray's Erinn Murphy, despite acknowledging that some of the company's initiatives — in mid-tier channels, international and footwear — are "proving more expensive than we once thought, we do not believe the ultimate opportunity for the brand has changed."Plus, athletic trends aren't going away anytime soon, wrote Murphy, who has an overweight rating on the stock."We view athletic as one of the only domestic softlines categories with both the ability to deliver reliable unit growth and pricing over the coming years," she said. "Our checks continue to indicate square footage expansion of the category across multiple channels into 2017."RELATED:Dow Dog Nike Comes Out Swinging; Bullish On North America, BasketballUnder Armour Dives On Growth Targets; Execs Vow To Invest 'Aggressively'

Apple (AAPL), Western Digital (WDC) and Micron Technology (MU) had their price targets raised Wednesday, while Under Armour (UAA) and Mobileye (MBLY) were downgraded.Apple had its price target raised to 140 from 125 by RBC Capital Markets, which maintained an overweight weighting.Apple late Tuesday reported that in the December quarter it beat revenue and earnings estimates thanks to better-than-expected iPhone sales. Apple sold 78.3 million iPhones during its fiscal first quarter, up 5% from the same quarter last year. Analysts were looking for 77 million units.Apple stock soared 6.1% to finish the regular trading session at 128.75 on the stock market today, an 18-month high and keeping the Dow Jones Industrial Average slightly positiveRELATED:Under Armour was downgraded to market perform from outperform and had its price target cut to 20 from 39 by FBR Capital Markets, one of about a dozen downgrades.Under Armour reported fourth-quarter earnings late Tuesday that disappointed and said CFO Chip Molloy is stepping down "due to personal reasons." During the key holiday shopping season, Under Armour logged a one-cent profit decline from the prior year to 23 cents a share on 12% revenue growth to $1.3 billion, the weakest gain in eight years.Under Armour stock ended the day down 0.2% to 21.44 after crashing 26% Tuesday.Mobileye was downgraded to equal weight from overweight and had its price target cut to 44 from 48 by Morgan Stanley, due to higher R&D costs and greater competition.Some analysts say the provider of driver-assistance technology is well-positioned in the race to develop self-driving cars.  In late December, Mobileye announced it will partner with digital mapping company Here, owned by a consortium of German automakers, to develop a precise global map that can be used for hands-free driving and location services. Add Sears Holdings (SHLD) and Sears-owned Kmart to the list of companies that are shedding some Trump-branded products — but the company insists that politics has nothing to do with it.The major retailer said on Saturday that Sears and Kmart would no longer carry several dozen Trump Home products, according to Reuters."As part of the company's initiative to optimize its online product assortment, we constantly refine that assortment to focus on our most profitable items," said Sears Holdings spokesperson Brian Hanover, according to a statement acquired by the outlet."Amid that streamlining effort, 31 Trump Home items were among the items removed online this week," he said. Those products were reportedly sold only online and not in brick-and-mortar Sears and Kmart stores.But responding to recent headlines via blog post, Sears said Monday that the changes reflect a routine shuffle of its product assortment and that "hundreds" of Trump and Ivanka Trump items are available on Sears.com through third-party marketplace sellers."I think any fair observer can understand why this confusion was generated and why we prefer to remain focused on serving our members and our marketplace sellers and leave the politics to others," wrote Sears Holdings Vice President of Corporate Communications Chris Brathwaite.Sears shares plunged 8.1% to close the regular trading session at 6.40 on the stock market today. But the stock rose nearly 26% Friday as the ailing retailer said it will slash costs further and could sell more core brands and real estate. The stock hit its lowest level since 2003 on Wednesday.Meanwhile, the Wall Street Journal reported Saturday a 32% sales decline of Ivanka Trump-brand merchandise at Nordstrom (JWN) in the prior fiscal year, citing internal Nordstrom data. The data also reportedly shows a more-than-70% sales tumble of the brand's footwear and clothing items in the second, third and fourth weeks of October vs. prior-year sales. Those weeks marked the period leading up to the election.IBD'S TAKE: With or without scrutiny from the president, retailers have been facing challenges, and malls have been forced to ramp up the drama in the age of Amazon (AMZN). Here's what that looks like.Boycotts of Trump-branded goods have surfaced in the form of the Grab Your Wallet campaign and criticism online. The President fired off a tweet at Nordstrom on Wednesday, less than a week after reports emerged that the upscale department store was dropping his daughters line of merchandise.My daughter Ivanka has been treated so unfairly by @Nordstrom. She is a great person -- always pushing me to do the right thing! Terrible!— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 8, 2017Nordstrom said the change was a reflection of sales performance.While this is far from the first time that Trump has singled out an individual company on Twitter (TWTR), his tweet at the department store has raised concerns about ethical conflicts of interests and a blurred line between his roles as president and businessman.Despite the attack, Nordstrom shares rose sharply on Wednesday to notch its biggest one-day gain in two months. But Nordstrom dipped 2.3% Monday morning.Fashion news site Racked.com has reported that Neiman Marcus, Belk, HSN and ShopStyle have dropped Ivanka Trump merchandise.Meanwhile, Wal-Mart (WMT)-owned Jet.com also appears to have pulled Trump-branded goods, Mic reported, though Wal-Mart itself still offers Trump merchandise.T.J. Maxx and Marshalls, both owned by off-priced retail specialist TJX Cos. (TJX), also seem to be pulling back on Ivanka clothing.In other news, Under Armour (UAA) CEO Kevin Plank is under fire from his own brand's endorsers after calling Trump "a real asset to the country" in a recent CNBC interview.RELATED:President Trump Attacks Nordstrom To Defend Daughter's Business Sears Could Sell More Brands, Real Estate To Cut $1 Billion

Technology startups faced a tough climate over the last year.The Bloomberg U.S. Startups Barometer, a weekly gauge that tracks both the funding flowing into private tech companies as well as the exits that make their investors money, is now near its lowest level since 2014. But venture capitalists are optimistic that things will turn around this year.For one, investors expect more initial public offerings this year. Last year was a particularly slow one for IPOs as well as acquisitions within the tech industry — so it's not surprising that investors expect 2017 will be better.The hope is that successful IPOs from some of the largest startups such as Snap (SNAP), which filed publicly last week for an initial share sale, will encourage smaller companies that have been on the fence to go public."Most bankers are predicting 30 to 40 IPOs, and that's up substantially over 2016," said Scott Raney, a partner at Redpoint Ventures. "A lot of companies think it's a good time to go public, and a lot of companies have the ability to go public."But the industry got a bit of a shock when AppDynamics, which was expected to be a trendsetter for the year's tech IPOs, announced a surprise sale to Cisco Systems (CSCO) the day before it was supposed to price its shares.Another reason for optimism is that venture capital firms are stockpiled with cash. VCs raised $41.6 billion in 2016, the most since 2001, according to research firm PitchBook Data and the National Venture Capital Association.With that amount of cash sitting on the sidelines, there's a good chance it will be put to use in the near future, said Nizar Tarhuni, an analyst at PitchBook.Also, the stock market is booming. On Jan. 25, the Dow Jones industrial average cracked 20,000 for the very first time.Public companies, "seeing their stock price go up, are more emboldened to acquire smaller companies," said Maha Ibrahim, general partner at Canaan Partners.Further, favorable policies could free up cash at big tech companies. President Trump has suggested cutting taxes on companies' accumulated offshore earnings to persuade them to bring back that money to the U.S. If his repatriation plan goes into effect, many companies may start making use of their overseas profits — not just to build factories and create jobs, as Trump has intended, but also to fund domestic investments."If that happens, I would assume there's going to be a ton of M&A," said Marvin Liao, a partner at 500 Startups. "There's a very good chance of that happening under his regime."Finally, even nontech companies are interested in startups. It's not just the tech giants like Alphabet's Google (GOOGL) and Facebook (FB) that are interested in startups — there's a new batch of buyers in industries like retail that are looking to acquire the talent, the strategies and the customer base that their smaller rivals have developed.There's been "a rush of nontech incumbents active in private tech markets as of late, like Wal-Mart (WMT) and Jet.com, Unilever (UL) and Dollar Shave Club, Under Armour (UAA) and MyFitnessPal," said Vas Natarajan, a partner at Accel Partners.For large companies, spending a few billion dollars to acquire a tech business is a small price to pay to mitigate the threats that these startups pose to their core business, according to Natarajan.RELATED:IPO Stock News And AnalysisWhat Are Today's Top-Performing IPOs?

J.C. Penney (JCP) and Nike (NKE) have joined forces to launch Nike "brand shop environments" in more than 600 J.C. Penney stores, the department store chain said Tuesday.The linkup between the midlevel department store company and major sports apparel brand pits them directly against another similar duo. Under Armour (UAA) announced last July a move to roll out products at around 600 Kohl's (KSS) locations starting early this year.On the surface, the most notable difference in the two alliances appears to be the gender of their target consumers.The 500 sq. ft. Nike shop-in-shops, which are now available, have been placed in a "prominent location within the men's department," said J.C. Penney, and will feature basketball, training and running product areas. The details found in the press release appeared primarily geared toward men's products, though the company said "similar visual elements are available in select stores for women and kids."Meanwhile, Under Armour Chief Executive Kevin Plank acknowledged last year that the majority of Kohl's customers are women shoppers."We think Kohl's is a great evolution for us," said Plank in Under Armour's second-quarter call in late July, adding he thinks there's "a big opportunity" in the women's market.IBD's TAKE: What's in store for American shoppers? A "reckoning," says one expert.The move comes at a time when athletic wear remains popular but department stores have largely been struggling to keep abreast of Amazon.com (AMZN) and other online shopping destinations.A brief postelection rally for department stores soon gave way to a downswing that was further weighed down by weak holiday sales figures. Macy's (M), Nordstrom (JWN), Kohl's, J.C. Penney have all been trading well below their key 50-day and 200-day moving averages.But shares of J.C. Penney advanced 2.7% on the stock market today, as retailers and apparel makers generally rallied following President-elect Trump's negative comments about a House GOP plan to tax imports. Nike climbed 1.4% and Kohl's 1.45%. Under Armour closed up 0.2%.RELATED:Wal-Mart, Best Buy, Apple Rally After Trump Pans GOP Border Adjustment TaxRetailers Face 2017 'Reckoning,' More 'Sad Malls' As Amazon Keeps Booming

United Parcel Service (UPS) is struggling with the e-commerce boom, while Charles Schwab (SCHW) launched a new stock trading pricing war.The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell back below that key level, but regained 20,000 on Friday on the January jobs report and Trump's move to ease Dodd-Frank and other financial regulation. The Dow fell 0.1% for the week while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rose 0.1%, with all three ending the week near record highs. Trump's immigration orders created conflict with tech firms and trading partners. Earnings were a mixed bag. The CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) rallied from extreme levels, but not by much.RELATED:Dow component Apple earned $3.36 a share, up 2%, on sales of $78.35 billion, up 3%, in the quarter ended Dec. 31. Both were better than expected and marked a return to growth after three straight quarters of year-over-year declines. Apple's current quarter guidance was conservative, as usual. Apple said iPhone 7 Plus demand outstripped supply, while services revenue up 18%.Apple shares rose nearly 6% for the week, hitting an 18-month high.RELATED:Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) reported a smaller-than-expected loss, above-forecast sales and a bullish outlook. Shares shot up nearly 15%, hitting a 9-year high. Nvidia (NVDA), which competes with AMD in graphics and some other markets, jumped ahead of its earnings this coming week. Apple chip suppliers Cirrus Logic (CRUS) and Qorvo (QRVO) topped quarterly views, but gave bearish guidance. Both stocks sold off Thursday.RELATED:Facebook EPS soared 78% to $1.41 while revenue rose 51% to $8.8 billion, both easily beating views but decelerating for a second straight quarter. Mobile ads account for 84% of ad revenue. Facebook reiterated that ad revenue growth rates would "come down meaningfully" in 2017, a deliberate move to avoid ad saturation.
